title: Why are group one elements strong reducing agents? - Quora

response.answer_text: Seeing as there are lots of well written answers about how group I elements most easily have a stable valence shell by dropping an electron shell, I’ll take the liberty of being a bit more technical. Yes, the Lewis dot model explains perfectly well why sodium and potassium are so weakly bonded to their lone valence electrons but if we dig deeper into the actual quantum mechanics, namely the effects of shielding and comparative energy levels, what we’ll see is that the real reason group one elements are “strong” reducing agents is the simple fact that virtually all other elements on the periodic table pull on those electrons with much more force. *Rant on Shielding, Electron Orbitals, and Energy Levels incoming… Let’s look at sodium and chloride as examples to keep ourselves grounded. They form a very common salt and they’re on the same row on the periodic table so my explanation will go smoother, though it will apply across different rows as well. The valence orbital for the outer electron in sodium is the 3S orbital (If you don’t know what orbitals like S and P are… I’d recommend a google search cause I don’t feel like writing a novel’s worth of words here would help anywhere). The valence orbital for chlorine is… 3p. Ideally (in a one electron hydrogen model) these two orbital types are degenerate, and even in the multi electron realities the two energy levels are really close. This means that the 3p electrons in chlorine and the 3s electron in sodium are both relatively similarly spaced from their respective nuclei. This means the overwhelmingly dominant factor in how tightly the electrons are bound, and by extension their energy levels, are primarily determined by the electromagnetic attaction exerted by the nucleus. Neutrons don’t exert any such force because they’re neutral so this means we’re only going to focus on atomic number. Sodium’s atomic number is 11. Chlorine’s is 17. This means there are 6 more protons pulling on all of chlorine’s electrons than there are for sodium. At this point, it’s not a tremendous leap to infer that if these two atoms were brought into close proximity, the chlorine atom’s much higher charged nucleus would pull an electron away from sodium. Now hold on, you might be thinking, what about the other electrons that cancel out chlorine’s charge? After all, initially both sodium and chlorine have zero net charge. Again, this comes down to the fact that in quantum mechanics approximations made with the Schrodinger equation electron shielding effects are weak enough to simply ignore and approximate to zero in comparison to the electromagnetic forces of the nucleus on any particular electron. But what about salts from different rows? This explanation so far fails to explain why, say, potassium fluoride is created as an ionic compound. Well, at this point it comes down to orbitals. Remember how both sodium and chloride had the number 3 assigned to their valence shells? That’s not just some arbitrary number but an objectively defined quantum number. The higher the quantum number, the “higher” the energy level of the electron orbital in question and the larger the distance from the nucleus. Potassium’s valence shells have the quantum number 4 while fluorine has a valence quantum number 2. No, this does not mean potassium’s electrons are twice as far from the nucleus as fluorine necessarily but it does mean 4s,p,d,f orbital electrons are much more weakly attached to their nuclei than 2s,p,d,f orbitals. This means it’s still reasonable for fluorine to drag the electron away from potassium as it has a space available in a lower quantum number orbital. And in case you ask, yes the row number on the periodic table does in fact tell you the quantum number of the valence shells. Though once you get into d orbitals and transition metals in general that system gets kind of muddled. Hope this helps expand the picture. Feel free to comment if something’s unclear or I made a mistake. (which I very well might have in my long answer)

Group one elements are strong reducing agents because they have one valence electron in their outermost shell therefore they are loosely bound by the nucleus causing them to increase in their atomic size and as a result their ionisation potential ( minimum amount of energy to remove an electron from the outermost shell ) is less. Thus, they could easily lose an electron making them good reducing agents.
